original_text:
**INSTITUTION
NEUROLOGY DISCHARGE SUMMARY
PATIENT NAME :
**NAME[AAA , BBB M]
ACCOUNT # :
**ID-NUM
**ROOM
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN :
**NAME[YYY M ZZZ]
ADMISSION DATE :
**DATE[Jul 04 2007]
DISCHARGE DATE :
**DATE[Jul 06 2007]
REASON FOR ADMISSION :
Intracranial hemorrhage .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
The patient is a very pleasant **AGE[in 80s]- year - old male with a past medical history dyslipidemia , coronary artery disease , hypertension , one episode of atrial fibrillation , and benign prostatic hypertrophy who presented with acute onset of difficulty using his right hand .
He was evaluated in the **INSTITUTION Emergency Department and underwent a CT scan of the brain , which showed a small left prefrontal hematoma .
Subsequently , he underwent an MRI of the brain as well as MR angiography of the head and the neck which showed a left posterior frontal lobe hematoma with a small amount of adjacent associated subarachnoid hemorrhage likely due to amyloid angiopathy however with a possibility of an underlying cavernous angioma .
Otherwise , the MRI of the brain was unremarkable and there was mild atherosclerotic plaque at the origin of the right internal carotid artery with an otherwise unremarkable extracranial and intracranial MRA .
The patient was also evaluated by the Neurosurgical Service who did not see any need for intervention secondary to the small size and the minimal dysfunction that the patient had .
The patient subsequently underwent a stroke workup by the Stroke Neurology Team and this was including a transthoracic echocardiogram , which showed a normal left ventricular size and function with normal left ventricular segmental function and an ejection fraction of 55% to 60% .
There was mild aortic and mild tricuspid regurgitation .
There was mild left atrial enlargement , and a saline contrast injection was negative for any right - to - left intracardiac shunt .
There was also no pericardial effusion noted .
Laboratorywise , a fasting lipid profile was obtained , which showed a triglyceride level of 81 , total cholesterol of 210 , LDL of 133 , HDL of 64 , and VLDL of 13 .
Because the patient had previously known poor reactions to statin , a statin was not initiated , however his niacin was continued .
Hemoglobin A1c was noted to be 5.5 .
During the hospitalization , the patient remained stable .
He was evaluated by physical therapy , occupational therapy , and physical medicine and rehab .
He was deemed safe to go home with outpatient physical therapy for his right hand dysfunction .
Therefore , the patient will be discharged home with outpatient rehab on **DATE[Jul 6 2007] without complications .
DISCHARGE DISPOSITION :
To home .
DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS :
Small intracranial hemorrhage as noted above .
CONDITION :
Stable / good .
ACTIVITY :
As tolerated .
DIET :
Cardiac , low sodium .
FOLLOWUP :
1. His primary care physician .
2. Stroke Neurology Service , **PHONE in 4 to 6 weeks .
Outpatient OT and therapy will be ordered .
DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS :
Include :
1. Aspirin 81 mg p.o. daily to begin 2 weeks from discharge .
2. Quinaglute 324 mg p.o. t.i.d.
3. We will be discontinuing his hydrochlorothiazide , but initiating Diovan HCT , which is a combination of valsartan and hydrochlorothiazide ( 25/80 ) 1 p.o. daily .
The patient will be discharged home on **DATE[Jul 6 2007] without complications .
___________________________________
**NAME[YYY M ZZZ]
Dictator :
**NAME[WWW XXX] , M.D.
**INITIALS
D :
**DATE[Jul 06 2007] 16:11:06
T :
